subject: RE: [junit] Anyone know of a decent debugger?
msgSnippet: ... Though I m not in the never use debuggers crowd (hey, I develop in C++), the advice above seems ludicrous in the face of unit tests.  Especially doing test
messageBody:
Holliday, Donald B. (LNG-SHEP) made a strange utterance something like this:
>In Code Complete Steve McConnell states "Once a routine compiles, put it
>into the debugger and step through each line of code. Make sure each line
>executes as you expect it to. You can find many errors by following this
>simple practice."

Though I'm not in the never use debuggers crowd (hey, I develop in C++),
the advice above seems ludicrous in the face of unit tests. Especially
doing test first design you shouldn't need to worry about side effects. If
you do you need to look at your coding style.

I most frequently find the debugger useful not when developing code but
when maintaining it. Before I can refactor some nasty code I need to
understand what it's doing so I run it through the debugger.


--
"The best programmers that I have ever met have an amazing ability to make
nasty sh*t disappear. *Poof*" Gareth Reeves -- reevesg@...
